Впервые время он брал за безналичный расчет под реализацию товар у оптовиков и продавал. Из-за конкуренции на рынке он был вынужден искать источник финансирования... В начале 2005г он узнала о программе кредитования «Микроинвест». Получив, первый кредит он начал за наличные деньги покупать товар у оптовиков по более низким ценам. После получения следующих кредитов у него появилась, возможность самому привозит товар. В данное время он привозит товар сам из Бишкека (Кыргызстан) Теперь она сама дает под реализацию мелким торговцам из кишлаков, что взаимовыгодно обеим сторонам. Часть прибыли она тратит на нужды семьи, а оставшуюся часть направляет в свой бизнес.

loans.use: Goods' assortment increasing

loans.name: Koser's Group

texts.en:
My name is Koser P., wife of Muhammad Arif. I live in a two-room brick house here in Multan, a mid-size city in Pakistan. I have an embroidery business and my husband has a loom. I want to grow my embroidery business and generate good profits for my family. I need a loan for this purpose and plan to buy cloth and threads, etc. in bulk. Buying in bulk is relatively cheaper and will allow me to save on cost per item.

There are few other women in my loan group and we together assume loan responsibility for each other. They are: Muqsodan B., who requires loan for her son’s grocery store; Mariam B., who needs a loan for her bangles business; Sajida B., who needs loan for her husband’s weaving and wants to take on bigger orders: Aziz B. requires a loan for her husband to repair his rickshaw. I want all of them to get loans so that they can also improve their businesses.

loans.use: Expand embroidery business

loans.name: Gloria's Group

texts.en:
This dedicated group of seventeen businesswomen has taken on the name “The Star of the South.” The star represents the importance of the group as a guide star for the women who are trying to improve their businesses and the lives of their families. These women all have separate businesses dedicated to the sales or the making of food and other goods, some sell recyclable goods like plastic, aluminum, and cardboard.

These women have the common goal of not only increasing their businesses, but to also provide the best opportunities for their children. By increasing their businesses they will have the savings to send their children to school and give them opportunities that they themselves were unable to have.

With this loan, the women will buy goods they need to sell including fruits, vegetables, recyclable materials and ingredients to make and sell Chipas, a favorite Paraguayan snack.

loans.use: To buy recyclable materials like cardboard, plastic, aluminum, and other types of metal.  The ingredients to make and sell Chipas, along with oranges, bananas, pineapples, melons, watermelon, apples, various refreshments.  Other merchandise includes cosmetics, linen, and thread.

loans.name: Elsa Maria

texts.es:
Mrs. Elsa is a 54 year-old married woman. Her husband works as a technician at a telecommunications plant. They have two adult daughters who are trained to work in the professional sector, but are currently unemployed.

Seeing herself in a difficult economic situation and recognizing the general lack of jobs in the country, Elsa decided to open her own business. This business is a small grocery/general store which she installed in her home along with the help of her husband. Elsa attends and manages the store, and at times is assisted by her daughters as well.

With a great deal of sacrifice these two parents have been able to educate and train their daughters to work in the professional world. It has been a great joy for them to see their daughters arrive at the point this point. They were only able to provide for their daughters’ education through the combined work of husband at the telecommunications plant and the wife in her general store. The store has enabled the family to have all of the necessities, and has bettered their quality of life.

The family is planning to develop the stores’ product line. To this purpose Elsa requests a loan with which she will purchase dairy products, perishable goods, personal hygiene products, and other items demanded by her clients.

Translated from Spanish by Casey Unrein, Kiva volunteer.

Doña Elsa tiene 54 años de edad, es casada, su esposo se desempeña como técnico en planta de telecomunicaciones, tiene 2 hijas, las cuales ya son mayores de edad y profesionales, pero se encuentran sin empleo. Viéndose en una difícil situación económica y la falta de oportunidades de empleos en el país, la señora decide emprender su propio negocio, el cual es una pequeña pulpería que instaló en su vivienda con apoyo de su esposo, la cual ella misma atiende y administra, en ocasiones sus hijas le ayudan. Con mucho sacrificio estos padres lograron preparar a sus 2 hijas, la mayor satisfacción será verlas hechas unas profesionales. Esto lo pudieron lograr con el trabajo del señor y los ingresos que perciben del negocio. El negocio le ha permitido a esta familia vivir con lo necesario, han ido mejorando su nivel de vida y piensan desarrollar una miscelánea. Para esto la señora solicita un préstamo para poder comprar productos alimenticios, lácteos, perecederos y de higiene personal, que tanto demandan sus clientes.

loans.use: Increase the inventory of her grocery/general store.

loans.name: Iris

texts.en:
Iris O. M. has a general store in the city of Pucallpa. From this store, which she runs in her home, she sells many popular products. She started the business two years ago after deciding to leave a market she had worked in for many years.

Iris is 43 years old with 5 children and is happily married. She loves her business, particularly because she gets to work from home and can be with her family. She is very social and loves building relationships with her customers.

A member of the community bank Amigas Siempre Unidas, Iris is requesting a loan of $400 to repay over 6 months. She will use the loan to buy rice, sugar, toilet paper, oil, and much more.

loans.use: To buy products for a general store, including: rice, sugar, toilet paper, oil, and much more

loans.name: Fatuma's Maua Women Group

texts.en:
Fatuma is 48 years old and is a married woman with 4 children, ages 38,28,26 and 24 years old. Fatuma owns a small salon. Every day, she works from 9am to 8pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $400 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more salon items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Neema, Fatuma, and Aisha, who sell charcoal and operate a cafe.

loans.use: To buy more salon items for her business.

loans.name: Salamatou

texts.fr:
Mrs. Salamatou B. was born on December 31, 1968 in Dapaong, in the far north of Togo. She is married and the mother of three children. Since 2001 she has been selling cereals but she is specialized in the sale of corn.

This first loan she is requesting in the amount of US$ 725 will allow her to acquire four big sacks of corn so that she can increase her income.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Madame B. Salamatou est née le 31 décembre 1968 à Dapaong à l’extrême nord du Togo. Elle est mariée et mère de trois (3) enfants. Depuis 2001, elle exerce le commerce de vente des céréales mais elle s’est spécialisée dans la vente du maïs.

Le premier crédit d’un montant de 300.000FCFA qu’elle sollicite lui permettra d’acquérir quatre (4) grands sacs de maïs afin d’améliorer ses revenus.

loans.use:
Purchase of 4 sacks of corn

Achat de 4 sacs de maïs

loans.name: Lelisa

texts.es:
Lelisa is an exemplary and hard-working woman. When she was a child her humble parents taught her how to produce a great variety of delicious bread, an activity which the family was always associated with. Through these long years of hard work, she managed to convert her bakery into her main source of income and thanks to that, she has also managed to provide advanced education to her children, who help her with her work in their spare time.

Lelisa plans to expand her bakery and for that she needs to purchase ingredients wholesale (flour butter, yeast etc.), to avoid passing on the normally increasing prices of these inputs onto her own customers.

Translated from [Spanish] by [Lisa Ritchie], Kiva Volunteer.

Lelisa es una madre ejemplar y muy trabajadora, desde niña, sus humildes padres le enseñaron a elaborar gran variedad de deliciosos panes, actividad con la que su familia siempre se caracterizó. A través de estos largos años de trabajo, logró convertir su panadería en su principal sustento económico, gracias a ello, le brinda a sus hijos, estudios superiores, quienes en sus horas libres la apoyan activamente en su labor. Lelisa tiene planeado seguir creciendo con su panadería, para ello requiere adquirir materia prima al por mayor (harina, manteca, levadura , etc) porque constantemente el precio de estos insumos van en aumento, desfavoreciendo así el costo de la canasta familiar de sus clientes.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients for the production of bread.

loans.name: Eko

texts.id:
Eko S. is a 32 year-old currently working as a distributor of children's toys. He sells children's toys to a retail agent who in turn sells them directly to customers. Toys come in many varieties; some for sale are made of plastic and paper. At this time he is proposing to borrow so that he can expand his business. He hopes that the income earned can boost his livelihood so that he can put aside savings for his child's education. Eko S. has one child with his wife Sri Romelah. They live on Jl. Pidada Denpasar, where they rent a house.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Aarati, Kiva Volunteer.

Eko S. (32) tahun, saat ini bekerja sebagai distributor mainan anak-anak. Dia menyalurkan mainan anak-anak kepada penjual eceran, yang nantinya akan langsung menjual ke konsumen. Adapun mainan yang dijual terbuat dari plastik dan kertas. Saat ini dia mengajukan pinjaman untuk dijadikan tambahan modal usaha. Diharapkan keuntungan yang didapat sekarang bisa meningkat dan bisa disisihkan untuk tabungan untuk pendidikan anaknya. Saat ini, Eko S. memiliki satu orang anak dari istrinya Sri Romelah. Mereka tinggal di Jl.Pidada Denpasar dengan mengontrak sebuah rumah.

loans.use: To increase working capital for his business

loans.name: Gregorio

texts.es:
Gregorio is 55 years old and lives with his wife Antonieta. He is a humble person dedicated to grow crops in the land he inherited from his parents.

During 30 years he has grown different types of agricultural products, this activity takes all of his day, early in the morning he leaves to work at the land and returns home in the evening. Agriculture has helped him cover his home expenses. He enjoys being in contact with nature, although its hard to work with difficult weather conditions that affect his production.

For Gregorio, having a healthy wife gives him strength to keep working hard. He will invest the money to buy products for improving his land, such as insecticides needed during rain season. In the future, he would like to invest in a different type of business, for when his physical strength is not suitable for agriculture.

Translated from Spanish by Sofia Burt, Kiva volunteer.

Gregorio tiene 55 años, actualmente vive con su esposa Antonieta. Es una humilde persona dedicada al cultivo de productos agrícolas en los terrenos que heredó de sus padres.

Desde hace 30 años se dedica a sembrar diversos productos agrícolas, esta actividad le toma todo el día, desde muy temprano sale rumbo a sus terrenos regresando en las tardes a su hogar.Este trabajo le ha ayudado a solventar los gastos de su hogar, además, el estar en contacto con la naturaleza le agrada, lo difícil que es batallar con las diversas inclemencias del clima que perjudican su producción.

Para Gregorio, el que su esposa esté bien de salud, le da fuerzas para seguir con las mismas fuerzas que de joven con su trabajo. Invertirá el dinero en la compra de productos que mejorarán sus terrenos, como los insecticidas, que son necesarios en tiempos de lluvia. Con el tiempo, desea invertir en un negocio diferente para cuando las fuerzas ya no le den para los campos.

loans.use: Purchase products for his land

loans.name: Hilario  De  Jesús

texts.es:
El señor Hilario M. se caracteriza por ser muy esforzado ya que se dedica a la actividad agropecuaria fuente por el cual alimenta a su pequeño hijo y a su esposa.

El señor M. específicamente se dedica a la producción de ganado lechero y la producción de granos básicos. Hoy en día la necesidad que él atraviesa es la urgencia de adquirir el recurso financiero para la compra de vaquillas para su respectiva crianza y además para la inversión en el cultivo. Por esta razón es que él acude a Ceprodel para obtener un crédito y de esta manera salir adelante en su actividad económica y continuar brindándole el apoyo a su amada familia.
texts.en:
Mr. Hilario M. is a very hard worker engaged in farming activities, which is how he provides for his young son and his wife.

Mr. M. specifically raises dairy cattle and grows basic grains. Currently, he urgently needs financing to purchase heifers and to invest in his crops. For this reason, he has come to Ceprodel to request a loan to proceed with his farming activities and continue supporting his beloved family.


Translated from Spanish by Amani Roland, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase dairy cows and invest in crops.

loans.name: Norma

texts.es:
Norma es socia del Banco Comunal Tarpuy que significa Sembrar en quechua. Norma es separada, tiene 26 años y 3 hijos, Norma vende golosinas, bebidas, en un triciclo que se ubica de manera ambulatoria en la puerta del Zoológico de la ciudad, actividad que realiza todos los días de la semana. Norma vive en la casa de su mama que se ubica cerca de su negocio.

Norma necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de galletas, gaseosas. Los sueños de Norma son que sus hijos estudien, tener casa propia y surtir con mas productos su negocio.
texts.en:
Norma is a member of the Banco Comunal Tarpuy (which means sow/plant in quechua). Norma is 26 years old. She has three children and is separated. Through the use of a tricycle, she sells pastries and drinks at the entrance of the city zoo. She works every day of the week. She lives in her mother's house, which is situated near her business.

Norma asks for a loan to purchase biscuits and sodas. Norma's dreams are to see her children study, have her own house, and provide more products to her clients.

Translated from Spanish by Marco Alves, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase biscuits and sodas

loans.name: Mathew Group

texts.en:
This is Isatu S., Fatu K. and Aminata K.. They named their group the Mathew Group. They are local entrepreneurs in the town of Makeni. This is the sixth time they’ve received a Kiva loan through SMT. Previously, each one in the group received a loan of 1,000,000 LE. That loan created meaningful impact in the lives of these people. They were able to use the proceeds to pay for their children’s school fees. They’re also able to feed and clothe themselves and their children with the income generated from the loans. Today, they are requesting a loan of 3,000,000 LE to buy more goods to add to their businesses.

Isatu S. (left) is the leader of the group. She is thirty-five years of age. She was born in Makeni, north of Sierra Leone. She is married with three children. Two of her children are in secondary school and one is in primary school. Her husband is a businessman who sells second-hand clothes. Isatu sells both soft and hard drinks in Makeni City.

With this new loan, Isatu will expand on her business. She will be able to buy at least twelve crates of soft drinks, seven crates of beer, three crates of Battery energy drink and three crates of power shakes. She travels to Freetown, which is 390 miles round trip, to buy the drinks. The fare to and from Freetown is 20,000 LE each, and she pays 100,000 LE for the crates of drinks she buys. So far, Isatu faces no major challenge worth noting. Business is going fine for her and she loves doing it. Her immediate goal is to buy herself a plot of land so that she can build a house. She is tired of renting!

loans.use: To buy supplies of beverages for resale

loans.name: Shani

texts.en:
Greatings from Tanzana!  This is 34 year old Shani Y. from Mwanza. She is married with four children, between the ages of 4 and 15 years old. Shani Y. has been operating a café business since 2002. The name of the café is "Mama Lishe". A local restaurant or café in Tanzania usually consists of a rough wooden table and some long wooden benches. The food is all-local; rice, ugali (a hot sticky dough, made from maize flour), plantain (a cooked savory banana), all served with beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of sauces. She works at her business 12 hours a day, 7 days a week and is assisted by one employee. Shani Y. currently earns about 450USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 425USD in order to buy beans, rice and vegetables. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Shani Y. thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To buy supplies of beans, rice and vegetables

loans.name: Felipe

texts.es:
El señor Felipe R. y su esposa tienen tres hijos, a los cuales les quieren darles lo mejor.
Ellos tiene la necesidad de la elaboración de una losa en la parte posterior de la vivienda y así sus pequeños tengan un espacio techado donde puedan jugar, sus planes es después que tengan ya la losa poner unas divisiones para un cuarto que sea para sus hijos.
Don Felipe R.  es empleado de una compañía de electricidad y su ingreso no le  permite realizar una inversión tan fuerte, por lo cual pide apoyo para completar su proyecto.
texts.en:
Mr. Felipe R. and his wife have three children to whom they want to give the very best. They need to poor a concrete slab to complete the back part of their house. That way their children will have a covered space where they can play since they plan to divide up the new area into sections with a room for the children. Felipe is an employee of an electricity company and his income does not allow him to make such an expensive investment. Therefore, he is asking for support in order to complete his project.

Translated from Spanish by Debra Faszer-McMahon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To poor a concrete slab for the back part of the house

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace A. is twenty-two years old. She is married and has no children for now. She lives with her husband in a commercial/farming community called Koforidua in the Ashanti Region of Ghana. Her husband sells glass products, and Grace is a seamstress by profession. She graduated from her apprenticeship barely two years ago and has been running her own business.

Grace sews for both men and women but she says most of her clients are women. She sews a variety of designs to sell. She also sews for clients who come in with their own fabrics and styles. Grace owns the shop in which she works. She wants a loan to procure fabrics such as linen, polyester, etc and sewing accessories such as lining, pins, etc. She lives with her husband in a rented apartment. She desires to work hard to save enough money to acquire a bigger and better workshop.

loans.use: To buy fabrics and sewing accessories

loans.name: Anonymous Group

texts.en: Seventeen people living in Preaek Doung village in Kandal province comprise this village bank loan, and they will use their individual loan shares for a variety of purposes. Mr. Sokha S., 38, is the president of the village bank. He works as a motorbike taxi driver and, additionally, cultivates vegetables on a plot of land that he owns. His wife, Mrs. Eam Sina, is employed in a garment factory. Mr. Sokha S. has two children, one of whom is attending the local school, while the other one is still too young to work or study. Mr. Sokha S. currently needs a loan to be able to plow his vegetable field.

loans.use: Improvements in farming efficiency

loans.name: Martin

texts.es:
Martín V. A. es un señor de 42 años de edad. Vive con su esposa y tres hijos: Gustavo, Jason y Estiven. Don Martín se dedica a la agricultura y toda su familia le ayuda un poco a la hora de la siembra y la recolecta de los cultivos. 
La comunidad en la cual vive Martín se llama El Sauce de Santa Teresita de Turrialba. Es una pequeña comunidad rural de unos dos mil habitantes. Sus pobladores se dedican a la agricultura y a las lecherías. El Sauce tiene un relieve irregular y mucho del terreno se mantiene como bosque tropical húmedo. La comunidad tiene paisajes muy pintorescos que combinan el bosque tropical con dos lindas lagunas, plantaciones de café y lecherías. El Sauce se localiza aproximadamente a hora y media en bus de Turrialba, el centro de comercio más cercano, sin embargo varias veces al año, el camino se vuelve intransitable por las lluvias que caen en la zona. Este es sin duda uno de los principales desafíos para la comunidad. Cuando no existían actividades muchas personas optaron por salir a buscar trabajos en Turrialba o en fincas bananeras ubicadas en el Atlántico de Costa Rica. Actualmente los precios del café y la leche han mejorado por lo tanto los vecinos buscan cómo invertir en proyectos en la misma zona.
Con Martín tiene un pequeño terreno de 1.2 hectáreas en el cual siembra diferentes cultivos como maíz, frijoles, plátano y café. Él tiene 27 años de dedicarse a la agricultura. Durante ese tiempo ha tenido épocas en las que le va bien y otras en la que tiene que lidiar con problemas como malos precios de venta o fenómenos naturales que dañan sus cultivos. El terreno lo logró comprar con un pequeño préstamo. Anteriormente tenía que alquilar el terreno para sembrar.
Don Martín está solicitando un préstamo para comprar fertilizantes, semilla de frijol y semilla de maíz. Con esto espera lograr una buena cosecha que pueda vender y ayudar a salir adelante a su familia. La cosecha la espera vender en la misma finca. 
Don Martín es cliente de la Asociación de Productores de El Sauce, una organización local socia de la microfinanciera EDESA. Gracias a su vinculación con esta organización ha obtenido ya 6 microcréditos y todos los ha cancelado satisfactoriamente. Los montos han ido incrementando desde los cien mil colones hasta los doscientos cincuenta mil colones. Actualmente don Martín necesita un préstamo por quinientos mil colones para comprar las semillas y el fertilizante.
texts.en:
Martín V. A. is 42. He lives with his wife and 3 children: Gustavo, Jason, and Estiven. Don Martín makes a living through agriculture, and his whole family helps him a little during planting and harvesting seasons. The area where Martín lives is called El Sauce de Santa Teresita de Turrialba. It's a small rural community with 2,000 people. They are dedicated to agriculture and dairy operations. El Sauce has an irregular landscape, and much of the land is mantained as tropical forests. The community has very picturesque landscapes which combine the tropical forest with lovely lakes, coffee plantations, and dairy farms. El Sauce is approximately an hour and a half from Turrialba by bus, the closest city. Several times a year, the road becomes impassable because of the rains that fall in the area. This is without a doubt one of the biggest challenges for the community. When there isn't any work, the people choose to look for jobs in Turrialba or on banana farms located in the Atlantic region of Costa Rica. Currently the prices of coffee and milk have improved, so the neighbors are looking to invest in projects in their area. Martín has 1.2 hectares, on which he plants different crops like corn, beans, plantains, and coffee. He has been dedicated to agriculture for 27 years. During this time, he has had seasons that have gone very well and others when he has had to battle problems such as bad prices or natual phenomenons that damage his crops. He obtained his land through a small loan. Previously he had to rent land to sow his crops. Don Martín is a client of the Association of Producers in El Sauce, a local organization that is a member of the microfinance institution EDESA. Thanks to his connections with this organization, he has already obtained six microcredits, and all of them have been paid back satisfactorily. The amounts of the loans have increased from 100,000 colones (180 USD) to 250,000 (450 USD) colones. Currently don Martín needs a loan of 500,000 (900 USD) colones to purchase seeds and fertilizer.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase bean and corn seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Djuma

texts.ru: Мусофиров Джума проживает в Варзобском районе .Возраст 62 года, вдовец. Имеет пятерых детей. Зарабатывает путем работы таксистом , используя свой автомобиль. Занимается этим видом услуг уже 33 года.Работает по маршруту Душанбе-Чорбог. В месяц получает около 700 сомони чистой прибыли.Чтобы отремонтировать автомобиль , он обратился к нам за кредитом , для того , чтобы закупить автозапчасти. Таким образом он сделает ремонт и сможет быстрее выйти на работу и обеспечить себя бесперебойной работой.
texts.en:
Djuma M. lives in the Varzob district. He is 62 years, a widower and has five children. He makes a living by working as a taxi driver, using his own vehicle. He has been providing this service for 33 years. He works on the Dushanbe-Charborg route. He receives a monthly profit of approximately 700 somoni. In order to repair his car, Djuma decided to obtain a loan and purchase auto parts. The loan will enable him to quickly repair his car and come back to work without much interruption.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of auto parts for vehicle repairs

loans.name: Rosela

texts.en:
Rosela A. is a scrap buyer. She is 30 years old, hard working mother who loves to sing and has 3 children. Her husband, Nemesio A. is helping her manage their scrap buy and sell business.

She is requesting a loan of Php 8,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy more scrap items to grow their business. She will sell her scrap items with 40% mark up value. This is what she uses to feed and clothe her family.

CEVI is reaching out more people especially the poor to start and have their own business. CEVI provides all their clients not just credit but trainings and insurance coverage as wel

loans.use: to buy scrap items to sell

loans.name: Esmeralda

texts.en: Esmeralda S. is a married woman with four children and lives in Alicomohan, Kitagpang, Sugbongcogon Mis.Or., in the Southern Philippines. The family owns a small variety store and are also suppliers of coconut shell. In order to cope with their daily expenses, they had to find additional revenue sources as well as double their efforts to double their income. They found a way to expand and improve their small business through accessing a micro-finance loan from HSPFI, a Kiva field partner.

loans.use: Purchase more inventory for the variety store.

loans.name: Erica

texts.es: Erica es una mujer de 26 años, muy alegre y conversadora, vive sola en un pequeño cuarto alquilado y es muy conciente de que tiene que trabajar duro para mejorar su futuro. Tiene una cevicheria (restaurante especializado en ceviche y platos marinos) en el mercado Tupac Amaru (Mercado importante de la ciudad de Juliaca), su negocio es muy concurrido, ya que su sazón es muy especial y agradable al paladar, ella es muy alegre y amistosa, por lo cual siempre recibe a sus clientes con una sonrisa en los labios. Erica espera tener en el futuro una cevicheria más grande, donde pueda atender a más clientes y brindarles mejores comodidades, lleva 4 años en este negocio y sabe que lo más difícil de su trabajo es comprar el pescado, ya que tiene que tener mucho cuidado en escoger lo mejor, para que su ceviche salga exquisito. Es el segundo préstamo de Erica con MFP, siempre ha sido muy puntual en sus pagos y espera serlo ahora también, es la socia más alegre de su banco comunal y siempre está haciendo reír al resto. Utilizará mil nuevos soles en hacerle arreglos a su cevicheria, el resto del dinero solicitado lo invertirá en comprar más ingredientes para sus platos.
texts.en:
Erica is a 26-year old woman, very happy and chatty, who lives alone in a small rented room. She is very conscious that she must work hard to improve her prospects for the future. She has a “cevicheria” (a restaurant specializing in ceviche and other seafood dishes) at the Tupac Amaru market (an important market in the city of Juliaca). Her business is very busy given her food is tasty and agreeable to the palate, and she herself is happy and friendly. She always greets her customers with a smile on her face. Erica hopes to have a larger cevicheria in the future, where she could tend to a greater number of customers and provide more comforts for them. She has been in this business for 4 years, and knows that the most difficult part of her endeavor is buying the fish itself. She has to be very careful to choose only the best so her ceviche turns out delicious. This is Erica’s second loan with MFP, and she has always been very punctual with her payments, and hopes to be this way again. She is the happiest member of her cooperative bank, and always makes her colleagues laugh. She will use one thousand soles to fix up her restaurant, and the rest of the funds requested will be used to buy more ingredients for her dishes.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To fix up her restaurant, and buy the ingredients she needs to make her dishes.

loans.name: Jonalyn

texts.en:
Jonalyn C. is from the city of Dipolog. She is 31 years old and married with two school-aged children. To make a living, Jonalyn raises pigs for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month.

In 2007, Jonalyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC, which she used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell. Jonalyn is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP to expand the shelter for her livestock. This will be her 5th loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand the shelter for her livestock.

loans.name: Kirimya 2 Nakabazi Immaculate Group

texts.en: Immaculate N. is a 40 year-old widowed mother of six children, three of whom are attending school; she is also looking after four other dependents, three of whom are in school. For the past three years she has been buying and   selling cattle. Immaculate is requesting the loan to purchase Frisian breeds of cattle for both milk and beef sales. She is an active lady whose dream is to also rear poultry.

loans.use: Purchasing Frisian breeds of cattle for milk and beef sales.

loans.name: Anecita

texts.en:
Anecita D. is from the town of Tamban Pta. Miray, Baliangao. She is 29 years old, married, with 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Anecita owns and operates a business venture in the food sector operating a fishing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from harvesting and selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. Anecita has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Anecita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Anecita has successfully repaid a previous loan  from PMPC. Anecita is requesting a new loan of 3,000 PHP which will be used to purchase a fishing boat. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Anecita from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase a fishing boat.

loans.name: Sor

texts.en:
R. is a single mother of fifty-eight years old and blessed with one daughter who is married and still lives with her in the family home. R. was married, but her husband died of senility years ago.

R. currently relies on her daily income from her farming business; she raises pigs and cultivates a rice crop. Since 1999, she has started in this sector with her daughter. After she sells off all her mature pigs to buyers, she is still lacking some money to acquire other pigs to continue raising. That is why she decided to look for a US$ 600 loan to buy pig feed and piglets to raise; with the rest of the loan she will grow a rice crop.

loans.use: To buy pig feed and piglets to raise and  grow a rice crop

loans.name: Jose

texts.es: José tiene 51 años, vive junto a sus 2 hijos, con quienes asumió el rol de padre y madre debido a la separación con su pareja. Su deseo de educar a sus hijos lo llevó a consolidar su propio taller de cerrajería, en el cual trabaja hace más de 10 años. Se inició con el apoyo de algunos amigos quienes le ayudaron a conseguir su primeros clientes y ahora ya tiene 2 talleres y un buen número de clientes, quienes solicitan sus servicios con frecuencia. Esta actividad le permite mejorar sus ingresos económicos, es por ello que una de sus metas es instalar sus talleres de cerrajería en zonas comerciales de su localidad donde le generen mayores ganancias. Pero para lograrlo trata de estar muy pendiente de sus dos locales, contando con el apoyo de sus hijos y su padre. Por tal motivo, para mejorar la calidad de su labor requiere de varias herramientas que espera modernizar, ya que las que posee ahora están gastadas. Este es su primer crédito con Microfinanzas PRISMA por lo que compromete a ser responsable con sus pagos y con la institución. Los 2500 soles que viene solicitando le permitirán comprar los materiales necesarios para realizar los acabados de los últimos trabajos que tiene por entregar.
texts.en:
José is 51 years old. He lives together with his two sons, with whom he has assumed the role of father and mother owing to his separation from his wife. His dream to educate his children led him to put together his own locksmith's shop, in which he has worked for more than 10 years. He began the shop with the support of some friends, who helped him to get his first customers. He now has two shops and a good number of customers who frequently solicit his services. This profession enables him to continue improving his economic income, and it is for this reason that one of his goals is to install his locksmith's shops in commercial zones, where the shops' locations would generate increased earnings. However, in order to achieve this goal, he must keep a watchful eye on his two locations; to help him try to do this, he relies on the assistance of his sons and father to keep the shops running smoothly. To be able to expand, he must improve the quality of the labor at his shops. To do this, he requires various tools that he has been waiting to modernize, since the ones he has are all worn out and need replacing. This is his first loan with Microfinanzas PRISMA, for which he promises to be responsible with his payments and toward the institution. The 2500 soles that he is requesting will permit him to buy the tools and materials required for him to complete the remaining jobs he has yet to complete for his customers.

Translated from Spanish by Kevin Lenhart, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Compra de materiales

loans.name: Marcelina

texts.en:
42-year-old Marcelina J. is a married woman who mothers eight children. Together with her husband, she ventured into a fish-vending and hog-raising business. Out of it were they able to build a small house and send their children to school. According to her, CEVI has played a big role in what they have achieved in life now.

Marcelina requested a loan of Php 15,000 to purchase additional pigs. She is hopeful that this loan will help her in maintaining their family business.

loans.use: To buy more piglets and feed and more fish to resell

loans.name: Maylen

texts.en:
Maylen T. is from the village of Lobogon. She is 27 years old, married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Maylen owns and operates a fish-vending business. The main source of income for the business comes from harvesting and selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. Maylen has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2005, Maylen joined Kiva partner PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maylen has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. She is requesting a new loan of 50,000 PHP, which will be used to make improvements to her house. This loan will be her ninth from PMPC. She plans to use the revenue generated from her business to improve her family's general living conditions and make further improvements to her house.

About PMPC
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To make improvements to her house

loans.name: Gul Sir

texts.en:
Gul Sir is the daughter of K.. She lives in Kabul, Afghanistan in a family of four members.

Gul Sir wants to take a loan for her husband who has a car-parts shop. He needs to cover all the necessities of his family and pay for all the expenses. He has a car-parts shop for which he still needs some tools.

Gul Sir is requesting an individual loan of 30,000 Afghani. Her husband is confident that, with the loan, he can increase his business.

loans.use: To enable her husband to buy tools for his business

loans.name: Deizi

texts.es:
Deizi, de 49 años, es una mujer muy alegre, vive en una habitación alquilada junto a sus 2 hijos: Fiorella de 20 y Gerson de 13 años y lo que más desea es darles una buena vida.

Su negocio es la venta de ropa de forma ambulatoria, todos los días recorre las instituciones públicas y privadas en busca de clientes que deseen comprar algo de lo que vende. La ropa la trae de la ciudad de Lima, es por eso que los modelos que vende son muy novedosos y llamativos.
Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es aconsejar a sus clientes sobre las prendas que están de moda, lleva 20 años realizando esta actividad y considera que lo más difícil es tener que caminar todo el día en busca de clientes. 
Para más adelante espera tener el dinero suficiente para tener una tienda donde pueda vender con mayor tranquilidad.

Este es el tercer préstamo de Deizi con MFP, está dispuesta a trabajar muy duro para pagar a tiempo sus cuotas, en su banco comunal es muy querida, ya que siempre le pone mucha a alegría a las reuniones. Con los 1000 soles solicitados comprará más ropa en la ciudad de Lima para poder ofrecer a sus clientes una mayor variedad para escoger.
texts.en:
Deizi, 49, is a very happy woman. She lives in a rented home with her two children. Fiorella is 20, and Gerson is 13. What she wants most of all is to give them a good life. She makes her living as a street vendor selling clothes. Every day she goes to public and private institutions looking for customers who want to buy something that she is selling. She brings the clothes from the city of Lima. That is why the clothes she sells are very new and striking. What she likes most about her work is advising her customers about what clothes are in style. She has been doing this for 20 years. The most difficult part is having to walk all day looking for customers. Later she hopes to have enough money to have a store where she can sell more calmly. This is Deizi’s third loan with MFP. She is prepared to work very hard to make her payments on time. She is much loved in her communal bank. She always adds a lot of joy to the meetings. She will use the 1,000 PEN that she is asking for to buy more clothes in the city of Lima so that her customers can choose from a greater variety.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase merchandise

loans.name: Raineria

texts.en:
Raineria P. is from the village of Mahinog, Camiguin. She is 50 years old, and is separated from her spouse. To make a living, Raineria works in the food sector making and selling barbecue products to the local community. (Her business is also known as "alacart.") Raineria joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Raineria is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Raineria from HSPFI.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & working capital.

loans.name: Carmen

texts.es:
La señora Julia es socia del  Banco Comunal “24 de Junio”, vive en el distrito de Ilave, provincia de El Collao, en el departamento de Puno. Ella tiene 37 años de edad y es casada. Se dedica a la compra y venta de animales menores.
La señora tiene estudios  concluidos de primaria y en su poder aun tiene a 3 hijos.
Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos desde hace 2 años atrás, su primer préstamo fue de  S/.300.00 nuevos soles el mismo que le sirvió para la compra de animales menores.

Ella solicitará un préstamo de S/.500.00 nuevos soles, el mismo que lo invertirá en la compra  de ganado: ovejas.
Su deseo para el futuro es abrir una tienda en Ilave.

Lo que mas le gusta de su organización es el ahorro que puede hacer.
texts.en:
Mrs. Julia is a partner in the 24 de Junio Community Bank. She lives in the district of Ilave, province of El Collao, in the department of Puno. She is 37 years old and is married. She works buying and selling young animals. She completed primary school and still maintains three of her children. She joined the Manuela Ramos Movement more than two years ago. Her first loan was for 300 new soles which she used to purchase young animals. She applied for a loan of 500 new soles which she will use to buy sheep. Her hope for the future is to open a store in Ilave. What she likes most about the organiation are the savings.

Translated from Spanish by Patrick King, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of sheep

loans.name: Vet

texts.en: Vet Y., 35, lives in the Takeo province with her husband and three children. To earn a living, she has been selling fish at the local market to earn approximately US$7 of profit per day. Her husband is a moto-taxi driver and makes US$3 a day. Vet Y. is asking for a loan of US$1000 to replace her husband's old and unreliable motorbike.

loans.use: To replace an unreliable motorbike.

loans.name: Hassan

texts.en: Hassan sells frozen foods. She has been in the business since 2006 and has been making a living out of it. She is 40 years old and is married with four children who are doing well in school. To increase her stock of frozen foods, which she buys from another distributor, she needs a loan of 150,000 Nigerian naira. She will use the loan to purchase more frozen foods to sell and meet her customers' demands. This will help to boost her income.

loans.use: To purchase more frozen foods to sell

loans.name: Djibil

texts.en:
Mr. Djibil F., age 30, is a new client of U-IMCEC in Thies, a city about 50 miles from sprawling Dakar. 

Djibil earned his diploma as an electrician in 1999, inspired by a long interest in all things electrical. However, he has found it difficult to find steady employment, so he supplements his income by raising chickens. Chickens can be a profitable activity, because each one can fetch as much as $6.00 in the markets. Djibil's older sister taught him the trade, and he has been raising chickens for about a year. 

With this loan of 300,000 frs (Communaute Financiere Africaine francs, also known as "XOF"), he will purchase 200 chicks and about a dozen 50-kg (~110 lb.) sacks of feed. He works closely with a local veterinarian, helping him to make sure the flock stays healthy. After 6 weeks, the chicks will be fully grown chickens that are ready for sale. 

Djibil says he will save the proceeds to pay for his upcoming wedding – an expensive affair!

loans.use: To buy chicks and feed

loans.name: Margaret Achieng

texts.en:
Margaret Achieng O. started doing business in 1987. Her first business was selling groundnuts (peanuts) to locals in Malanga, Busia district where she lives. She is currently running a cereals business selling maize and buys her stock from Uganda once every two weeks.

Margaret Achieng would like a loan of KES 10,000 which will go to expanding her business by increasing her stock.

loans.use: To increase her stock of maize

loans.name: Gina's Group

texts.en:
Gina B. is from the village of Cabisera 25. She is 33 years old. Gina is the leader of a 8-member loan group sponsored by ASKI. Although each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for repaying the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Gina B..

Gina is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Gina manufactures and sells wood products to local businesses and community members. Gina has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 20,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Gina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gina has successfully repaid a previous loan from ASKI. She used her previous loan to purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products. Gina is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP to purchase additional raw materials to expand her product offerings. This will be Gina's second loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional raw materials for her wood products business

loans.name: Ali

texts.en: Ali is a 49 year-old man who lives in Bint Jbeil southern Lebanon with his wife and their five children. Ali has owned a shoe shop since 2007. He decided on this business because of his experience in shoe sales and likes his work. He requests a loan from A. Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for the coming season. This is the first time that he has requested a loan. His clients are people from his region. In the future, he plans on improving his store.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for the coming season.

loans.name: Sina

texts.en:
Sina P. is 28 and married with no children.  She owns a business venture, selling traditional handicrafts to tourists and local community members.  Sina has many years of experience in this business.  Sina needs a loan of WST $1750 to purchase raw materials to make additional handicrafts.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 550 talas or US $229 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2007, Sina joined SPBD.  This is her 3rd loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Sina's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

The following social metrics for Sina P. are provided by SPBD*:
Overall Social Metric Score:                1.5 out of 3
Level of Education:                              1.5 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:         1.6 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:              1.65 out of 3

*SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress. The overall social metric score, provided by SPBD, is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation. A higher number represents a higher score. For example, a ""3 out of 3"" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a ""2 out of 3"" = secondary/high-school, and a ""1 out of 3"" would mean that the borrower is uneducated.

For more information on this score, please see SPBD's partner page at: http://partners.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=15

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to purchase raw materials to make additional handicrafts

loans.name: Noime

texts.en:
Noime B., 53, is making sure that her family has enough provision for their daily needs. Married to Folro B., a tricycle driver, she is blessed with three children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing her own egg stall and doing direct selling of cosmetics for eight years now.

Noime has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings* and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her egg-selling and cosmetics direct-selling businesses.

To ensure the success of her business, Noime would like to apply for a PHP 16,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business by buying more quantities of products to be incorporated into her inventory.

Noime dreams that her businesses will continue to be successful. She also prays that her family will continue to be closer to each other and with the Lord.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more eggs and cosmetics to sell

loans.name: Rosa Adelia

texts.es:
Roda Adelia F. es una mujer trabajadora, emprendedora, creativa y con visión. Ella inicio hace año y medio por medio de la ayuda de su hermana con la venta de aceite de cocina lo cual distribuye de manera ambulante en carretera norte.  
Ella con el crédito comprar mayor cantidad de aceite lo cual le permitirá aumentar el volumen de ventas.
texts.en:
Roda Adelia F. is a hard working woman, enterprising, creative, and with vision. About a year and a half ago with the help of her sister she started selling cooking oil which she distributes as a walking vendor along the north highway. With this loan she will buy a larger quantity of oil which will permit her to increase the volume of sales.

Translated from Spanish by Daniel Burke, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cooking oil for resale

loans.name: Las Campanitas De Loma Group

texts.es:
Este grupo se llama Las Campanitas de Loma está conformado por  9 y se ubica en el Estado de México en México.
Yolanda Jiménez C. es la tesorera del grupo. Tiene 34 años, estudió la preparatoria, es ama de casa y comerciante y tiene en total 3 hijos, 2 mujeres y un varón de 17, 11 y 7 años de edad respectivamente.  Ella se dedica a la compra y venta de dulces que inició hace 2 años con un pequeño puesto ambulante a un costado de la iglesia en el cual trabaja de sábado a jueves y el día viernes lo emplea para ir a surtir su mercancía. Platica que a base de los créditos y con las ganancias que sus ventas le han generado se apoyó para comprar un automóvil que le sirve para trasladarse a comprar su mercancía y para transportarla a diferentes puntos de venta cuando hay eventos en el pueblo, en los que participan varias comunidades de los alrededores y se instalan muchos puestos para toda la gente que se reúne. Solicita el préstamo para invertir en la compra de más dulces y botanas, y de ser posible comprar también jugos y refrescos con la intención de acrecentar su negocio y continuar participando en las eventualidades que se organizan en su comunidad, pues ella espera obtener mas ganancias que con el paso del tiempo le permitan construir un local y tener su propia dulcería, mejorando también su calidad de vida. 

Los otros integrantes del grupo son:
- Ana Lilia R. V. (Venta de Ropa Interior)
- Agripina C. (Venta de tortillas)
- Silvia C. R. (Venta de ropa)
- Rosa María C. G. (Venta de ropa)
- Petra B. A. (Venta de dulces y plásticos)
- Verónica C. V. (Venta de dulces y refrescos)
- Marcela V. C. (Venta de zapatos)
- María del Rocío R. B. (Venta de ropa)
texts.en:
This group is called “Las Campanitas de Loma” (Loma’s Little Bells); it has 9 members and is in Estado de México, a Mexican state. Yolanda Jiménez C., 34, is the group treasurer. She finished high school and is a housewife and merchant; she has three children, two girls and one boy who are 17, 11 and 7 years of age respectively. She is a candy merchant; she started out two years ago with a small sales cart alongside a church; she was open for business from Saturday through Thursday, she used Fridays to stock up on merchandise. She relates that based on loans and profits from her sales she was able to buy a car that she uses to go get her merchandise and transport it to various points of sale when there are events in town where many outlying communities participate and many booths are set up for all the people that gather. She is asking for funds to buy more candy and snacks and, if possible, juices and beverages with the intention of expanding her business and continue participating in the events the town organizes because she expects to get more profits that will make it possible for her to build a proper candy store in the future thereby improving her quality of life. The other group members are: - Ana Lilia R. V. (Underwear Sales) - Agripina C. (Tortilla Sales) - Silvia C. R. (Clothing Sales) - Rosa María C. G. (Clothing Sales) - Petra B. A. (Candy and Plastics Sales) - Verónica C. V. (Candy and Beverage Sales) - Marcela V. C. (Shoe Sales) - María del Rocío R. B. (Clothing Sales)

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy more candy and snacks and, if possible, buy juices and beverages.

loans.name: Benmar

texts.en:
Benmar B. is from the village of  Baluarte, Cagayan de Oro City. He is 25 years old. Benmar is single. To make a living, Benmar owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling firewood in the local community. Benmar has been engaged in his business for over 2 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Benmar joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Benmar is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Benmar from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Baluarte, Lumbia, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Alaska Group

texts.es: Doña Herlinda Lucia Perechu T., tiene 47 años de  edad,  se dedica al comercio (en la compra y venta de ropa típica etc.) su negocio ya cuenta con 5 años de estar funcionando, vende los días Domingo y jueves en Nahualá  y con eso logra el sustento diario. Conjuntamente con otras vecinas deciden organizar un grupo para poder solicitar un préstamo. El cual será utilizado como capital de trabajo y así poder  incrementar el volumen de ventas y sus ganancias. Son 3 señoras que conforman el grupo Solidario denominado, GRUPO ALASKA las señoras de dedican a diversas actividades productivas como lo es la compra-venta de ropa típica en dicha localidad.
texts.en:
Herlinda Lucia Perechu T. is 47 and sells and buys traditional clothing. She has been in this business for 5 years. She sells every Sunday and Thursday in Hahuala, and with this she earns her daily bread. With other neighbours she decided to organize a group to request a loan. It will be used as working capital to increase sales volume and their earnings. This group named Groupo Alaska is made up of three women who engage in various productive activities such as the purchase and sale of traditional clothing in their area.

Translated from Spanish by Christine Cooper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Almakan's Group

texts.en:
Almakan O. is the leader of the group. She is 39 and a widow. She has raised two sons and two daughters; the older son studies at university and the others are at school. In order to make money, Almakan, with the initial investment of 10,000 soms, started to purchase fruit and vegetables and resell them on the market at a higher price. In this way she plans to earn 5000 soms per month. With money received from the loan, Almakan wants to purchase various kinds of vegetables in order to resell them at the market. In the future she wants to stabilize her business and increase her turnover.

Chynarkan Z., 33, is the treasurer of the group. Her husband is a concrete worker on the hydro station. They have two sons and a daughter; all of them study at school. In order to make money, Chynarkan and her husband’s sister sell dairy products and national drinks near the road. She started with the initial investment of 5000 soms and now she makes 3000 soms per month. Chynarkan applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase dairy products to increase their turnover. In the future she plans to expand her business and purchase some land for farming.

Tynara K., 33, is married. Her husband works as a driver. They have two sons and a daughter. In order to make money,a year ago Tynara started to sell dairy products and national drinks near the road. She started with the initial investment of 10000 soms and now she earns 5000 soms per month. That profit made it possible for her to purchase a vehicle for her husband. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase dairy products and honey to resell. 

Satkankul U., 56, is a widow. She has raised five sons. The first son is a welder, the second is in construction; the third son is a soldier and the others went to work in Russia to earn some money. A year ago Satkankul started to breed livestock; she started this activity with the initial investment of 10,000 soms. Now that she has five sheep and three goats, Satkankul can sell one goat or one sheep a month if she needs money. She wants to get a loan to purchase sheep to increase the number of livestock and resell some of them after fattening. In autumn she plans to earn some money and purchase a cow.

 --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young, ambitious and socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). Mol Bulak is the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the Mol Bulak Finance staff.

loans.use: to purchase vegetables for resale

loans.name: Bipana

texts.en:
Twenty-eight-year-old Bipana B., a married mother of two children aged 10 and 7 months, established her tea shop business this year. Working seven days a week for seven hours each day enables her to support her family. Bipana has already received and repaid a loan from BPW which she used to increase her store's inventory. In the future, she plans to promote and expand her business, and she thanks you for your support.

Whether on the streets of Kathmandu or in the villages outside of the capital, tea shops are places of business and meeting in Nepal. Called a chiya pasal, these tea shops make a sweet, milky tea that can be purchased for a few cents a cup. With a Kiva loan, BPW's borrowers are able to keep their store shelves stocked while increasing their profit margins by buying in greater volume.

This loan was administered by Kiva's local partner, MFI, Patan Business and Professional Women. Patan BPW became Kiva's first field partner in Nepal in 2007. Operating throughout the Kathmandu Valley, it offers microcredit and business training programs to low-income women. In addition to providing economic opportunity to its clients, Patan BPW seeks to empower Nepali women within the home and community.

For more information about Patan BPW, visit our partner page and keep an eye out for new loans and borrower updates. Join our lending team: BPW Lending Team

loans.use: To purchase goods for tea shop

loans.name: Flordeluna

texts.en:
Flordeluna C. lives in the village of Tabon in Zamboanga del Norte. She is 44 years old, married and has seven children. For the last eight years, she has made a living by running a general store, and earns about 5,000 PHP a month. Last year, she joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid two previous loans from PMPC and is applying for a new one, her third, to buy additional supplies to sell and increase her access to working capital. She plans to use the additional revenue made possible by this loan to improve and expand her business.
       
About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy additional items to sell to her customers

loans.name: Allen

texts.en:
Allen is married with four children and two of her children go to school.  She owns a food stall in  Namungoona  market. She sells food staffs like bananas, sweet and Irish potatoes and tomatoes.  She has been in this business for over five years. She buys her food supplies from Owino and Kasubi markets and uses public transport to and from shopping. She goes shopping three times a week.   Allen wants to use this loan to buy more bunches of bananas, bags of sweet and Irish potatoes and baskets of tomatoes.  

She sells to all categories of people and at retail only. Allen works seven days a week. Her business challenges are transportation of food stuffs from Owino to Kaw Namungoona  and seasonality.  She aspires to see her business grow big and start going directly to farmers for supplies.  She decided to work with MCDT because of the low interest charged.  Allen resides in and owns a two roomed house and the family has access to electricity but no piped water.  Her monthly expenses include school fees and medication.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas, sweet and Irish potatoes  and tomatoes

loans.name: Jamsranjav

texts.en: Jamsranjav N., 38 years old, lives with his wife and five children in Uvs province of Mongolia. His oldest four children, ages 10 to 17, attend a local secondary school while the youngest, age 2 years old, stays at home with Jamsranjav's wife. Jamsranjav operates a horse-cart business in his town. He carries supply loads and people from the local market to various destinations. For each trip, he earns between 3,000-5,000 tugriks (MNT). His business earnings are currently not sufficient to take care of his family; therefore, his wife is planning to operate a boot-making business. In order to start the new business, the couple needs to have start-up capital. They estimate they will earn 12,000 MNT per day as business profit. They are very modest and hardworking people. His wife says, "I am planning to make many boots and sell them. With our business earnings, we want to open savings accounts in a bank for our children." Jamsranjav is requesting a 200,000 MNT loan to purchase raw materials for 10 boots in order to begin the new business.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials for boots

loans.name: Prossy

texts.en:
Prossy N. lives in the Mulago neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is single and has 7 children, six of whom are in school. She also takes care of additional family members. Prossy has a business as a beauty salon.  She has been in this business for over 10 years, and she works 7 days out of every week. Prossy sells her products from home at retail.  Prossy has requested a loan of 600000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more boxes of cosmetics cream relaxers and braids. 

She also generates additional income through farming. The main business challenge(s) for Prossy include rainy season and defaulters. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a bridal salon and also educating her children up to university. Prossy lives in a home that she rents. She has access to electricity and piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include rent, school fees and medication.

loans.use: To buy more boxes of cream relaxers and braids,

loans.name: Olivo Floresmilo

texts.es:
Olivo Floresmilo V. S. tiene 60 anos. Es casado y vive en el cantón de Chillanes en la Provincia Bolívar. Tiene 8 hijos de 36 hasta 25 anos. 

Olivo es socio de la ventanilla rural Progreso Comunitario, que está ubicada a dos horas de Chillanes. Son 11 socios en total, que en la mayoridad se dedican al cultivo de cacao o tienen sus propios pequeños negocios.  

Olivo se dedica a la agricultura. Tiene cultivos de cacao, ineo (un banana pequena), y el orito. Hace las compras y las ventas de sus productos en Babahoyo una vez al mes. 

Solicita el credito para crecer mas cacao. Con el apoyo del préstamo le ayudaria en ser mas solvente económicamente. Su meta es mejorar sus cultivos de cacao. Dice que hay una enfermedad ¨mal de machete¨y ¨escoba de bruja¨ que se caen el cacao. 

En su tiempo libre cose ropa y trabaja en el sistema de agua en la comunidad. Celebra las fiestas patronales en Octubre y el Carnaval en Febrero.
texts.en:
Olivo Floresmilo V. S. is 60 years old.  He is married and lives in the Chillanes Canton in the Bolivar Province.  He has 8 children between the ages of 36 and 25.  

Olivo is a member of the rural group, Progreso Comunitario, which is located 2 hours from Chillanes.  There are 11 members total, of which the majority work in the cultivation of cocoa or own small businesses. 

Olivo works in agriculture.  He has cocoa, "ineo", and "el orito" (small types of bananas).  He purchases and sells his products in Babahoyo once a month.  

He is seeking a loan in order to be able to grow more cocoa.  This loan will help him be more economically stable.  His goal is to improve his cocoa cultivations.  He says that there is a "bad machete" sickness and a "witch's broom" that has fallen on the cocoa plant.

During his free time, he sews clothes and works on the water system in his community.  He celebrates the local holidays in October and Carnival in February.

loans.use: Purchase cocoa supplies

loans.name: Angelito

texts.en:
Angelito V. is from the village of Poblacion 2, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. He is 54 years old. Angelito is married and has five adult-aged children. To make a living, Angelito owns and operates a motorcycle transport service. He has been engaged in his business for over two years and earns approximately $463 a month for this activity.

In 2009, Angelito joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 40,000 PHP from GDMPC. 

Angelito is requesting a new loan of 40,000 PHP which will be used to repair an existing vehicle for better service. This will be his 3rd loan from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to repair an existing vehicle for better service

loans.name: Maria Elena

texts.es:
La  señora Z. T. Maria Elena tiene 25 años de edad y vive en la casa de sus padres en un barrio de la ciudad de Tarija. Maria Elena es madre soltera tiene una hija. Maria Elena se dedica al comercio de verduras actividad que viene realizando desde hace mas de 6 años esta actividad la realiza en el mercado campesino.                                                                                                                                                                                                      
Maria Elena quiere tener mejores ingresos para brindarle una mejor vida a su hija pero ella nos cuenta que quiere comprar mas mercadería es por eso que el credito sera destinado para la compra de mercaderia para de ese modo poder incrementar sus ingresos.                                                                                                                                                                                                        
Maria Elena  nos cuenta que quiere darle a su hija toda la comodidad que pueda para que sea feliz, por eso nos dice que el proximo credito que solicite sera para la compra de un lote de terreno.
texts.en:
Sra. Maria Elena Z. T., age 25, lives at home with her parents in one of the neighborhoods in the city of Tarija. She is a single mother with one daughter. Maria Elena is a vegetable merchant who has been in business for more than six years at the farmer’s market.

She wants to improve her income so that she can provide a better life for her daughter and indicates that she would like to buy more vegetables. Therefore, this loan will be used to buy merchandise so that she can increase her earnings.

Maria Elena says she wants to give her daughter all the comforts to make her happy. With the next loan that she will request, she plans to buy a plot of land.

loans.use: Purchase more vegetables for her business

loans.name: Jasmin

texts.en:
Jasmin D. is a 40-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating two business ventures: a fishing business and a food-vending business. She lives in Purok Pasayan, Brgy. Tomongtong, EB Magalona, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2007 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts.  By working hard in her fishing and food-vending businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 5500.   

Jasmin is now borrowing PHP 18000 so that she can continue to fund the operations of her fishing business. This will be her seventh loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 15000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Jasmin aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well being by following the Dungganon way.  

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable"). Through the program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To fund her fishing business

loans.name: Gregorio

texts.en:
Gregorio G. is from the town of Trinidad. He is 50 years old. Gregorio is married and has five children. His eldest child is 27 years old and the youngest is 17. Just like any other father, he only wants the best for his family. He works hard to make them happy and healthy. To make a living, Gregorio raises livestock, primarily pigs, for fattening and sale.

Gregorio joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his business and living situation. Gregorio has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Gregorio is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP, which will be used to purchase pig feeds and vitamins. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to pay for his children's school fees.

loans.use: To purchase pig feeds and vitamins

loans.name: Nomeriana

texts.en:
Nomeriana S. is a 62-year old widow who supports her family by operating a candle making and selling business. She lives in Buntol, Brgy. Montañeza, Malabuyoc, Cebu. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2004 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her candle making and selling business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 5,000. Nomeriana is now borrowing PHP 10,000 so that she can purchase raw materials. This will be her ninth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 7,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Nomeriana aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams.
